marketNews.title: Other Hot Topics
marketNews.content:
1. Reuters reported that China and India, the world’s largest thermal coal importers, have reduced imports of Indonesian thermal coal and are shifting to higher-calorie coal from other countries because the global coal price decline makes high-calorie coal more competitive. Vasudev Pamnani, director of I-Energy Natural Resources, said high-calorie coal can generate more energy per US dollar despite a higher price per ton. He estimated that one million tons of high-calorie coal could replace 1.2-1.5 million tons of Indonesian coal. Analyst Zhiyuan Li of Kpler noted that medium- and low-calorie Indonesian thermal coal is now competing with discounted Russian supply of the same calorific value. Kpler recorded that Indonesia’s thermal coal export volume fell 12% YoY to 187 million tons in the first five months of 2025.
2. Reuters reported that the Indonesian government plans to introduce a new regulation requiring e-commerce platforms to collect a sales tax from sellers. The tax rate would be 0.5% of seller revenue for sellers with annual turnover between 500 million rupiah and 4.8 billion rupiah. The measure aims to boost state revenue and level the playing field between online and offline stores. The regulation could be announced as early as next month, but e-commerce platforms oppose it. The Ministry of Finance declined to comment, and the Indonesian E-Commerce Association (idEA) neither confirmed nor denied the report.
3. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani said the government remains committed to fiscal discipline while implementing President Prabowo Subianto’s priority programs. She projected the 2025 state budget deficit to reach 2.5% of GDP as targeted and indicated that additional policies will be introduced to stimulate consumption, investment, and trade to achieve the 5.2% YoY economic growth target for the year.
4. Labour Minister Yassierli said that as of 24 June 2025, the wage subsidy program (BSU) had been disbursed to 2.45 million workers, about 14% of the total target. The low uptake is due to multi-step verification and validation processes. The government aims to reach 17.3 million workers earning below 3.5 million rupiah per month, with a subsidy of 300,000 rupiah per month for June and July 2025.
5. PT PLN reported electricity sales grew 6.17% YoY in 2024 to 17.78 TWh. PT Pertamina Patra Niaga reported retail, corporate and subsidiary fuel sales rose 5.6% YoY in 2024 to 105 million kiloliters.
6. DNET CEO Haliman Kustedjo said the company has long considered taking PT Indomarco Prismatama (operator of the Indomaret retail network) public on the IDX, but an IPO is not expected in 2025. The company is still evaluating Indomaret’s financial condition before proceeding.

marketNews.title: About Defensive Investors
marketNews.content: "Reserve funds are not idle money. They are silent gold, ready to save the day when everyone panics." – Husin1030

tickerNews.title: BMRI 5M25: Net Profit Flat YoY
tickerNews.content:
Bank Mandiri (BMRI) recorded a net profit for the bank-only entity of 4.5 trillion rupiah in May 2025, down 2% YoY but up 26% MoM. This result makes the net profit for the first five months of 2025 (5M25) 19.7 trillion rupiah, a 0% YoY change, roughly in line with consensus expectations that projected a flat consolidated net profit for 2025F (+0.3% YoY).
Month-by-month, BMRI performance improved in May 2025 after the Lebaran holiday. The overall 5M25 performance, which generally resembles 1Q25, indicates that 2Q25 trends will not differ much from 1Q25, except for a potentially significant change in June 2025.
Non-Interest Income (Non-II) grew 6% YoY in May 2025, leading to a 13% YoY increase for the 5M25 period. Meanwhile, Net Interest Income (NII) slipped 1% YoY in May 2025 and grew only 4% YoY over 5M25.
The weak NII performance was mainly caused by a sharp rise in interest expense amid tight liquidity conditions. This is reflected in the Net Interest Margin (NIM), which was low at 4.39% in May 2025 and averaged 4.45% for 5M25 (vs. 4.86% in 5M24 and 4.46% in 1Q25). The 5M25 NIM is also below the 2025 guidance from management after adjusting for bank-only versus consolidated figures.
Compared with 1Q25, the annual growth rates of Non-II and NII over 5M25 are not far apart. In 1Q25, Non-II and NII grew 15% YoY and 6% YoY respectively.
Operating expenses (Opex) rose 6% YoY in May 2025, resulting in a 22% YoY increase for the 5M25 period. This increase offset income growth, causing Pre-Provision Operating Profit (PPOP) to be flat, down 1% YoY both in May 2025 and over 5M25.
Provision expenses increased 7% YoY in May 2025 but fell 6% YoY over 5M25. The reduction in provisions is reflected in a lower Cost of Credit (CoC) of 0.7% for 5M25 (vs. 0.87% in 5M24), also below the 2025 guidance after the bank-only adjustment.
Key Takeaway: Liquidity remains a major challenge, so any easing could be a positive catalyst for BMRI. Market expectations have already priced in most performance pressure, as consensus has cut the 2025F consolidated net profit estimate by 3%-9% over the past three to six months. As of Wednesday 25 June, BMRI traded at a valuation of 1.46x 1-Year Forward P/BV, nearly touching one standard deviation (1.42x) below the five-year historical average. At this level, BMRI offers a potential dividend yield of at least about 7%.

tickerNews.title: Hartono Brothers Acquire 3.64% of HEAL Shares at Premium
tickerNews.content: HEAL (Medikaloka Hermina) announced that PT Dwimuria Investama Andalan has taken over approximately 559.2 million treasury shares of the company at a price of 1,875 rupiah per share, about 36.4% above the HEAL share price on Wednesday 25 June. The acquired treasury shares represent a 3.64% ownership stake, and after this transaction HEAL no longer holds any treasury shares. PT Dwimuria Investama Andalan is owned by the Hartono brothers, Robert Budi Hartono and Michael Bambang Hartono, who also hold shares in Sarana Menara Nusantara (TOWR) and control Bank Central Asia (BBCA).

tickerNews.title: Gudang Garam Announces 2024 Dividend
tickerNews.content: Investor Daily reported that Gudang Garam shareholders approved a dividend plan for fiscal year 2024 amounting to 962 billion rupiah, or 500 rupiah per share. This corresponds to a dividend payout ratio of 98% (versus 0% in 2023) and implies a dividend yield of 5.6% as of Wednesday 25 June. The record date and payment date have not yet been announced.

tickerNews.title: Bangun Kosambi Plans Up to 1 Trillion Rupiah Share Buyback
tickerNews.content: Bangun Kosambi Sukses plans to conduct a share buyback with a funding allocation of up to 1 trillion rupiah during the period 25 June to 24 September 2025. The company did not disclose the number of shares to be repurchased. This plan does not require shareholder approval, following a relaxation granted by the OJK to support market stability. Previously, CBDK announced a buyback plan in March 2025, but there has been no change in the number of outstanding shares from February 2025 to the end of May 2025.

tickerNews.title: Total Bangun Persada Reports New Contract Value of 2.17 Trillion Rupiah
tickerNews.content: The Corporate Secretary of Total Bangun Persada, Anggie S. Sidharta, told Kontan that the company recorded a new contract value of 2.17 trillion rupiah during the first five months of 2025, a 17.3% YoY increase, representing 43.4% of the 2025 target of 5 trillion rupiah.

tickerNews.title: Lo Kheng Hong Holds Approximately 5.02% of SIMP Shares
tickerNews.content: Lo Kheng Hong is recorded as holding about 778.86 million shares (5.02%) of Salim Ivomas Pratama, according to KSEI data as of 24 June 2025. The transaction value is unknown. Previously, Lo Kheng Hong did not appear in the list of SIMP shareholders with ownership above 5%.

tickerNews.title: Bekasi Fajar Targets 600 Billion Rupiah Marketing Sales in 2025
tickerNews.content: Leo Yulianto Sutedja, President Director of Bekasi Fajar Industrial Estate, said the company targets marketing sales of land amounting to 600 billion rupiah in 2025, a 48.1% YoY increase compared with the 2024 realization of 405 billion rupiah. He also mentioned that BEST aims for stable recurring income growth, focusing on warehousing and logistics, consumer goods, food and beverage, and data center sectors, especially in the MM2100 industrial area in Bekasi, West Java.

tickerNews.title: HOKI Targets At Least 10% Sales Growth in 2025
tickerNews.content: Kontan reported that Buyung Poetra Sembada, CEO of HOKI, targets a sales growth of at least 10% YoY in 2025, aligned with a national distribution expansion strategy and the launch of high-value-added products through the 'Daily Meal' line. Director Budiman Susilo also said the company is preparing a new plant worth 15 billion rupiah for producing 'Daily Meal' rice in Boyolali, Central Java, with production expected to start in September or October 2025.
